title: Monday, 2nd October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

Morning

PM11:02am

Erm, where to start?

PM11:03am

There's precious little corporate news, but lots of other proper news

PM11:03am

PM11:03am

PM11:04am

Oh, things just fine -- we've been given seats on BA. Very nice.

11:04 am

Thumbs up

PM11:07am

Uncertaintyin Spainfollowing Catalonia’sindependence referendumPreliminary results show 90% in favour of independence (participation around 43%) -link.While the referendum is not recognised by the Spanish Constitutional Court or the international community, Catalan’spro-independence leaders have stated that if the ‘Yes’voteprevails they would callfor a declaration of independence within two days regardless of the participation rate. We see secession as highly unlikely(link), but seeno quick fixes either;both sides are radically opposed, and tensions could rise in the coming days if a declaration of independence is proclaimed

PM11:07am

We remain shy of Spanish equitiesAfter an impressivestart tothe year, the Spanish equity market has been under pressure since May due to thestrengthening of the euro. While othereurozone equitieshaverebounded since September courtesy of a pausein the euro rally, the IBEX 35 hasunderperformed by c.2%(p.2), a lag that coincides with the Catalan parliament approving the referendum on 6 September. A combination of a minority government and the Catalan independence push might prevent Spain from makingmuch-needed reforms, hencewe remain shy of Spanish equities.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Catalonia-related stocksIn close coordination with SG equity analysts, we have revisited theCatalonia-related basket we put together three years ago (link).Below welist 18stocks exposed to Cataloniaand potentiallyat risk on a relative basis if tensions and uncertainties were to riseor that could benefit if tensions were to ease. Since the Catalan parliament approved the referendum on 6 September, our list of stocks has underperformed the IBEX 35 by -3.3%

BE11:09am

As in, 3% of the UK market

PM11:09am

Is that all??

BE11:09am

Yep. 4% of slots at Gatwick, 5% at Luton and 6% at Manchester.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Plenty of reports over the weekend that there's a slot grab going on already. Easyjet, Wizz, IAG all reported to be trying to get.

Wizz Air Holdings PLC (WIZZ:LSE): Last: 2,948, up 87.34 (+3.05%), High: 2,951, Low: 2,876, Volume: 312.16k
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 602.00, up 8.5 (+1.43%), High: 608.00, Low: 590.00, Volume: 2.94m
11:11 am

Course, we can see the broader picture. Air Berlin and Alitalia have both failed.

BE11:11am

Blame tends to be on the price war in the Med ......

PM11:11am

I was about to ask

11:11 am
BE11:12am

..... rather than fuel price hedges rolling off, which is a more complicated explanation.

BE11:12am

Here's Morgan Stanley .....

BE11:13am

The UK Civil Aviation Authority will co-ordinate the recovery of around 110,000 customers now abroad, with assistance from company employees and the administrators - however the CAA announcement makes clear that flights booked on the scheduled services are not ATOL protected and are not entitled to make a claim to the CAA. Luton-based Monarch has 35 Airbus A320 family aircraft and a single Boeing 737. Based on current 2017 schedules for Monarch's scheduled operations, the company operated 7.56m seats, which represents around 0.85% of total EU-28 capacity, but 5.6% of total UK-EU capacity. The cessation of operations should be to the benefit of the Top 3 main players in the UK market - EZJ 22.5%, RYA 19.5% and BA 16.6% share (including domestic and UK-EU seats).
In addition, we estimate, this will free up around 350 pilots and 550 cabin crew based on crewing ratios of around 5x per aircraft, likely alleviating some pressures cited in recent weeks on pilot availability.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@Pseudonym: haven't seen a stat to back that up.)

BE11:14am

I flew Monarch once.....

BE11:14am

..... because it was the only flight I could get out of Alicante airport during Semana Santa.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

It wasn't really my thing.

BE11:14am

The only food on board was a full English. It was served in a kind of wax paper dog bowl.

BE11:15am

Anyway, tour operator readthrough. Similar arguments.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Credit Suisse:

BE11:15am

This morning the UK civil aviation authority has confirmed Monarch Airlines and Monarch Holidays (traded as Cosmos Holidays historically) has ceased trading. With a heritage as a leisure and tour operator driven business, Monarch had significant route overlap with TUI and Thomas Cook. Seat capacity data shows a Q3 2017 8.0% share of seats from UK to sun and beach destinations - defined as Spain (8.6% share), Portugal (12.8%), Greece (1.8%), Turkey (6.4%) and Cyprus (7.8%). This compares to a 12.9% for TUI, 7.1% for Thomas Cook and EasyJet 19.7%. We would anticipate Monarch slots becoming available through the process with Sky News having reported interest from EasyJet last week. Monarch’s 5-6% share of London Gatwick, London Luton and Manchester slots, per 3Q17 flight data, may well appeal to EZJ, allowing it to expand its footprints in some of its most profitable bases (LGW in particular). The UK trading backdrop for tour operators has been tough in 2017 with high levels of competition noted - most notably to Spain. The 2018 UK outlook has been one of our most significant concerns given the full impact of fuel and fx hedges rolling off and the associated high single digit price rises that will likely be needed. Whilst this dynamic is unaltered by today's news, the competitive pressure should at least partially ease.

BE11:16am

So, yeah. A wee bit more pricing power to offset fuel and FX.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

But as I remember it, the sector is still doing 5% short-haul capacity growth isn't it?

BE11:17am

Or at least claiming to, assuming Ryanair can locate enough people to fly the planes.

BE11:18am

JP Morgan as well, since we're here.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Monarch (not listed) went through a heavy
turnaround after October 2014 under the private equity ownership of Greybull Capital, and had in 2015 already announced that its previously separate package holiday brand, Cosmos, would be folded into the main Monarch brand, with “the tour operating division now focused on supporting the Monarch scheduled network of airline destinations and building its hotel accommodation portfolio around those locations". Package holidays represented only c5% of Monarch volumes in 2016.

BE11:19am

Price positioning could favour TUI as the clearest alternative. Based on FY16 data, we estimate
Monarch’s package travel offer was on the “premium” side of the market, with average selling prices of c£723, above the market average of c£687. On this perspective, the TUI brands Thomson and First Choice could appear as the clearest beneficiaries. Note that European Tour Operators do not report average selling prices, but based on UK revenue, volume, and mix comments, we have previously estimated TUI to be positioned at above market price points, and Thomas Cook at below market price points. However these relative positionings may have been shifting rapidly in recent years, and Monarch’s current distressed situation is described in press reports as stemming from volume pressure in some of its traditional markets including Turkey and Egypt. TUI previously estimated that Monarch could control up to 10% of the market in 2016.

BE11:20am

I'd no idea the package holiday industry was so concentrated.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

BE11:21am

So, we're running a deficit of about 1.1m homes

PM11:26am

So in response we get Help-to-Fund housebuilders divis.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Yes. The housebuilders have done literally nothing to close this gap since Help To Buy was introduced in 2013, or indeed before.

BE11:28am

All that's happened is that they're back to running a 20-25% operating margin, like they were for several decades apart from that wee blip around 2008.

BE11:29am

And for what? For a subsidised newbuild system where people are flogged flats on a 5% deposit?

11:29 am
BE11:29am

In a market where newbuild pricing has adjusted higher to offset the subsidy?

BE11:29am

Creating a huge problem for the secondary market to digest?

BE11:30am

It is a terrible policy. Literally the worst housing policy it's possible to think of.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

You're sounding pretty furious about all this Bryce

BE11:31am

Well ... I am. I like people to have houses. Instead, we've had 400% returns for an effective cartel industry that has been incentivised by hopeless government policy to hoard landbank and not build houses.

BE11:32am

Anyway, let's focus on the winners here.

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Welcome to ML

BE11:33am

We had expected an extension but potentially
changes to the specifics of the scheme, including the % lent, price caps (currently £600k) and other restrictions. There have been some questions marks around the Government's support for the scheme over recent months. As such, the announcement will likely come as a relief for investors exposed to the new build residential market.

BE11:33am

Since its inception in Q2 2013, a total of £6.7bn of equity loans have been issued supporting 135k new-build homes. Over the past 12 months up to Q217, the run rate of loans issued was £2.5bn and since inception the annual average has been £1.5bn, suggesting £10bn of funding could imply an extension of 4 to 5 years. Help to Buy has been supporting c1/3 of private completions in England over recent years, but varies significantly by company

11:33 am
BE11:33am

We think an extension of the Help to Buy scheme is positive for the UK housebuilders and should give investors confidence that the high rates of return generated could persists longer. The new build sector has been supported by the scheme, in our view, which allows buyers to buy a new build property with a 5% deposit, while benefitting from low mortgage rates of a 75% LTV mortgage. We have previously calculated this implies a cash saving of c20% vs renting and c30% vs purchasing with a 95% LTV mortgage, making new build highly compelling to potential buyers.

BE11:34am

(@Lefevre: show me any evidence whatsoever that HTB has stimulated housebuilding.)

BE11:34am

And Numis .......

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Since the scheme's launch in April 2013 and June 2017, 134,558 homes have been bought through the Help to Buy equity scheme, and equity loans have amounted to £6.7bn (supporting the purchase of £32.4bn of homes). The mean purchase price of properties bought under the scheme was £240,530, and the mean equity loan was £49,963. 81% of the loans have been used by first-time-buyers.
To put the scale of the new pledge into context, the new funding is 50% greater than the loans issued under the scheme in its first four years and it will add to unutilised funds of £5.4bn at June 2017. The value of equity loans granted in 2016 was £2.1bn (£1.36bn in H1 2017) and therefore at the current run-rate the additional funds should
extend the scheme by a further 4/5 years through to c.2025.
The scheme is material for the quoted UK housebuilding sector (and associated companies) with roughly 40% of private completions using the scheme. The biggest user of the scheme under our coverage is Persimmon (54% of private completions) and Berkeley is the smallest user.

BE11:36am

And JPM.

BE11:36am

[£10bn] means that we assume that any additional funding guarantees the scheme’s future comfortably beyond the current end date of 2021. At some point, we also expect redemptions to also help fund the scheme as initial buyers start to sell properties. Therefore our initial view is that the end date is likely to be extended well into the 2020s, potentially something close to the Labour party 2017 manifesto commitment of 2027.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

(@Lefevre: still waiting for that evidence.)

Irrational exuberance in 2018 would be best exemplified by tech mania causing financial conditions to tighten later in 2018; note that in 1989, Nikkei bubble drove JGB yields higher, 1999 Nasdaq bubble drove UST yields higher and so on; another good signal would be a widening of FAANG credit spreads (Chart 5)

PM11:40am

PM11:40am

10 of these

11:40 am
PM11:40am

Revoking online liability exemptions, potentially making tech companies vulnerable to lawsuits and prosecution based on user-posted content (bipartisan Senate bill introduced in August, S.1693)
New antitrust and patent laws, possibly including retroactive penalties for mergers that fail updated standards (see LinkedIn court case, Warren "Better Deal" Senate bill, Steve Bannon call for regulating tech "public utilities")
Tougher antitrust enforcement: $2.7bn: amount Google fined for antitrust violations by the European Union
Recent ban of Uber by London Mayor; UK opposition party threat to ban Airbnb
New internet consumer privacy protections (Blackburn House "Browser Act")

PM11:40am

New regulations on political advertising disclosures (Warner-Klobuchar Senate bill)
New Commerce Dept. committee on impacts of AI & automation on workers (Cantwell Senate bill)
South Korea has just proposed the world's first "robot tax" by reducing automation incentives
Trump's immigration policies (H1-B visa and ‎DACA reviews) could make tech labor more expensive
Facebook acquiescence in government demands for details on its largest political advertisers, and abandoning plans to issue 5.7bn shares of non-voting stock

Greencore Group PLC (GNC:LSE): Last: 182.50, down 13.7 (-6.98%), High: 196.60, Low: 181.40, Volume: 9.52m

BE11:46am

Here's Numis.

BE11:46am

The immediate impact on financials of the product recall is minimal and we make no changes to forecasts. However we think that the market's reaction (shares down 6%) reflect concerns over Greencore's ability to win new business to fill its legacy sites. We accept that this news is not helpful but would highlight that this is a supplier issue and that the recall was a precautionary measure. As such we do not think that the recall will hamper the development of the US business. Sentiment and momentum are against Greencore but fundamentally we think that Greencore remains attractively valued. We reiterate our Buy rating and 300p TP.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

(@BornCynic: Darwinism.)

BE11:47am

The recalled products amount to c.3 days of production from the Rhode Island site. This we estimate equates to c.$300k of sales which in the context of the overall US business expected to deliver £913m of sales in FY 2017e. As such we expect minimal impact on numbers and make no changes to forecasts. We forecast £142.3m of adj operating profit in FY 2017e (consensus range £140-144m).

PM11:50am

Meanwhbile, you know globally -- we are on the second longest bull run since 1969...

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Extraordinary -- when you think of the news backdrop

PM11:50am

Here's SocGen

PM11:51am

Global equity markets rose 2.1% in September, with MSCI World surpassing 2000 for the first time and in turn delivering its eleventh successive month of positive total returns. This ranks as the second longest period of consecutive gains for MSCI World since its formation in 1969, with realised volatility collapsing as a consequence. Such a long period of gains, coupled with exceptionally low volatility, inevitably builds up risk in the financial system; low volatility is simply high price confidence and when confidence in asset prices is high, investors do risky things.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

The bulls will claim that this latest rise in equity markets has been supported by resurgent profits, and they would not be wrong. MSCI reported profits rose by 20% over those 11 months and the actual reported P/E has fallen a shade. However, EPS levels are merely back to where they stood in November 2014, when MSCI was 15% lower, and overall profits have yet to exceed 2008 levels when the index was a third lower. Essentially QE sustained equities levels in anticipation of a profit recovery, but rather than de-rating as those earnings came through, markets are simply being propelled to ever higher levels. The equity valuation problem was created during the 2011-15 era when global profits went nowhere, yet equities rose 30%.

PM11:51am

The acceleration in equity markets that started around 18 August has seen several previously weak areas rebound strongly. The Russell 2000 in particular has been bolstered by renewed Trump ‘Tax Talk', and the stocks of those companies with the weakest balance sheets (which we think will be in the eye of the storm in the next downturn) rallied strongly, gaining 20% from their mid-August lows. Short investors in the Russell 2000 have already been burned by Trump's election, so it remains to be seen if the latest reversal of short positions in the ‘bad balance' sheet segment is simply profit-taking until tax plans are digested or a genuine fundamental reappraisal of US small cap balance sheet risk. For the timing being we are inclined to think it is the former.

PM11:51am

That's the every readable Andrew Lapthorne

11:53 am
BE11:54am

What else? HSBC has a rather underpowered fantasy M&A thing out on the luxury goods makers.

BE11:54am

Nice cover, tho.

BE11:54am

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Assuming that's a stock image rather than a picture of Erwan.

BE11:55am

Here's the gist.

BE11:55am

As we explained in our 27 March 2017 thematic report A dear hunt, we believe a combination of
decade-high valuation levels, large amounts of cash, low interest rates (see our strategists’
Themes you can use report, 27 September 2017) as well as a change in the luxury business
model (from growth linked to store openings to more of a like-for-like focus) implies a greater
likelihood of deals happening. Management change, activism and theoretical targets, often the
subject of press speculation (eg Burberry, Tod’s, Ferragamo, Tiffany), have supported an
expensive sector. Much has happened in the last six months, with LVMH purchasing the Dior
Couture brand, Coach acquiring Kate Spade and Jimmy Choo joining the Michael Kors group.
We explain in this follow-up report that we expect M&A to remain a theme over the next 12
months as predators digest their acquisitions and possibly gear up for more ahead. Our
previous M&A report focused on acquirers and here we look at listed and unlisted companies in
the sector that the bigger players, notably LVMH, Kering, and Coach, might wish to consider.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Unlike other consumer sub-sectors, we don’t believe there are many synergies to be derived from
acquisitions in the luxury space. So, why bother and how do you justify the prices paid? We continue
to see two rationales for M&A in luxury. Either you purchase the long-term growth prospects of your
targeted acquisition (theoretically, smaller companies should grow at a faster pace than larger ones
and some categories (eg jewellery) have better growth prospects than others (eg fragrances).
Or, you buy an asset because you think you can do better than the current management team.
All the M&A activity in the sector since the 1999-2001 frenzy has featured at least one of the two
rationales above (buy growth, better management), and sometimes both. The interesting thing about
the current phase of the industry’s cycle (see our strategy piece The M&A hunting ground) is that
cash is piling up, valuations look high and management issues have multiplied. In other words, we
believed the sector was ripe for M&A back in March, and luxury sector events as well as macro
issues since have not made us change our minds at all. Although timing and names are impossible
to predict, we think much more transformation is likely for the sector from an M&A point of view.

BE11:56am

There's a lot more of that, but they're sellers of Burberry so we can't really put it on a news peg.

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,791, up 31 (+1.76%), High: 1,795, Low: 1,764, Volume: 356.85k

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,370, up 30 (+2.24%), High: 1,387, Low: 1,349, Volume: 2.78m
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Mr Agarwal’s Indian metals and mining arm Vedanta Limited has now completed its merger with Cairn India and its market value ($18.7bn) is closing in on Anglo’s ($22.7bn) — something many analysts and investors appear to have overlooked. (Add in the value of Vedanta’s London-listed vehicle and the company’s are worth almost the same.)

Given Mr Agarwal’s stated ambition to turn Vedanta into a “complete natural resource company” to rank alongside BHP Billiton, there is every reason to think that his Anglo share purchase is more than just an investment. 

BE12:02pm

......... kinda happening in plain sight, this one. Surprised Neil's the only one who's written about it in depth.

BE12:02pm

........ and that's about it for the weekend roundup.
